content.webTitle: Blue Mythologies by Carol Mavor review – reflections on a colour

fields.headline: Blue Mythologies by Carol Mavor review – reflections on a colour
fields.bodyText: Julia Kristeva has said that “colour is not zero meaning: it is excess meaning”. Art historian Carol Mavor’s evocative and eclectic collection of essays demonstrates how true this is. Drawing on the history of art, photography, literature and her own memories, Mavor dives deep into an ocean of blueness: “My stories seek blue (duplicitous) truths which nevertheless ring true.” She regards blue as being a “particularly paradoxical” colour: “blue is the purity of the Virgin Mary, yet blue names a movie as obscene”. Blue is – as Rebecca Solnit has said – the “colour of longing for the distances you never arrive in”. It is also the scattered light of the sky and the sea, Van Gogh’s irises, the eternally elusive blue flower of Novalis and Romanticism, the icy blue of glaciers as well as “the snobbery of aristocratic blue blood” and “the struggle of blue collar workers”. It’s the blue of the Hindu god Vishnu (“the optimistic colour of heavenly, infinite life”), of delicate Chinese porcelain and of cyanotypes, camera-less photographs created by placing objects on to light-sensitive paper, such as Anna Atkins’s ones of sea algae from 1843: exquisite blue and white images reminiscent of Matisse’s paper cutouts. Sumptuously illustrated throughout, Mavor’s writing – inspired by Roland Barthes’s Mythologies – is rich with insights, both theoretical and personal. She segues effortlessly from her dreams (“blue reveries in the darkness of my mind”) and her mother’s illness (“How does one mourn someone still alive, yet who is not of this world?”) to blue in literature: Proust’s aquamarine-eyed Albertine; how for Nabokov the letters of the alphabet were coloured by the blues of synaesthesia (“a steely x, thunder-cloud z, and huckleberry k”), to Thomas Mann’s Death in Venice and Aschenbach’s destructive desire for Tadzio. To quote Colette, Mavor is without doubt a true “connoisseur of blue”. • Blue Mythologies is published by Reaktion (RRP £14.99). To order a copy go to guardianbookshop.com. Free UK p&p over £15.
